dataset.title: Identification and detection of Bougainvillea spectabilis chlorotic vein-banding virus in different bougainvillea cultivars in Taiwan

abstract.para: A new virus disease of bougainvillea occurred in Taiwan and proved to be caused by a Badnavirus, which is similar to the pathogen tentatively named ‘Bougainvillea spectabilis chlorotic vein-banding virus (BsCVBV)’ in Brazil according to pathological and molecular results. In electron microscopic observations, typical bacilliform virions measuring 130–158×27–42 nm were observed in infected bougainvillea tissues. The transmission tests demonstrated that the virus could be easily transmitted among different bougainvillea cultivars by bud grafting but not by mechanical inoculation. BsCVBV showed different pathogenicity to various bougainvillea cultivars in our inoculation tests. The Taipei-Red and Thimma cultivars showed the apparent foliar symptoms of chlorosis, chlorotic spots, wrinkling and leaf-distortion; the original species of Bougainvillea glabra produced chlorotic spots and vein clearing on leaves without wrinkling or leaf distortion; both ‘Mrs. Eva Mauve Variegata’ and Hati Gadis showed mild mottling and faint spots of leaves; Helen Johnson was tolerant to BsCVBV. Our devised PCR-based assays demonstrated that BsCVBV could replicate and persistently survived in all tested bougainvillea cultivars used in this study although it induced different symptoms in them. The BsCVBV-1 primer pair devised from our cloned BsCVBV-specific DNA fragments proved to be efficient in the PCR assays for the rapid and specific detection of BsCVBV in Taiwan, and this PCR-based method is helpful in the quarantine, inspection and ecological studies for BsCVBV in Taiwan.

section.title: Plant and virus sources
section.para: The diseased bougainvillea plants suspected to be infected by BsCVBV were collected from the Taipei-Red cultivars (Bougainvillea buttiana, a hybrid derived from Bougainvillea Glabra×B. peruviana), which were previously grown on the campus of National Taiwan University in Taipei. These infected bougainvilleas exhibited symptoms such as mottling, chlorosis, vein banding and stunting. They were directly used in the identification of pathogen, and the one showing the most apparent and severe symptoms was further propagated by the cutting method for a donor plant of inocula in the graft-inoculation tests.

Five additionally important bougainvillea cultivars in Taiwan such as B. glabra ‘original species’ (ORI), B. glabra ‘Mrs. Eva Mauve Variegata’ (MEMV), B. glabra ‘Hati Gadis’ (HG), B. buttiana ‘Helen Johnson’ (HJ) and Bougainvillea spectoglabra ‘Thimma (TH) (Vicky)’ (a hybrid derived from B. spectabilis×B. glabra) were used in the bioassays with graft inoculation aside from the Taipei- Red cultivar for comparative symptomatology. All these 3 cultivars with different morphological properties in their flowers and leaves (Cullen, 2001; MacCubbin & Tasker, 2002) were originally obtained from the nursery or greenhouse at the Department of Horticulture at National Taiwan University and were tested for BsCVBV infection using the PCR assays described later to confirm that they are free from BsCVBV. To avoid the possibility that the parts of genomic DNA of Badnavirus integrated into the host genome, all vegetative materials such as grafting budwoods and cutting twigs for propagation of healthy bougainvilleas must be BsCVBV free through the confirmation of PCR assays. The BsCVBV-free cultivars were used as mother plants to produce more seedlings for further inoculation tests.

section.title: Mechanical inoculation and graft inoculation with BsCVBV
section.para: For biological identification, the BsCVBV extracts from diseased bougainvillea tissues were used to inoculate several indicator plants such as Chenopodium amaranticolor, Chenopodium quinoa, Datura stramonium, Nicotiana glutinosa, Nicotiana benthamiana and Nicotiana tabacum through mechanical transmission. The inoculated plants were kept in a greenhouse under temperature control at 25℃ for the observation of symptom development.

Budwood grafting methods of Su & Chu (1984) and Yoshida (1996) were chosen for the graft inoculation. In total, six bougainvillea cultivars as described abovewere inoculated with the BsCVBV-infected scions of the Taipei-Red cultivar by grafting. Each cultivar had four replicates of seedling (50 cm tall, 1-year old) for the objective results, and each receptor plant was graft inoculated with two diseased scions at the 10- and 40-cm positions from the top of bougainvillea seedling. Grafting was judged successful when the scions survived for more than 3 months after grafting. All the inoculated bougainvillea seedlings were grown in a greenhouse under temperature control at 25℃. Symptom development was observed and recorded periodically, and all tested plants were sampled monthly for total nucleic acid extraction followed by the PCR-based detection of BsCVBV. The healthy bougainvillea seedlings without graft inoculation were also prepared for the negative controls under the same growth conditions.

section.title: Transmission electron microscopy
section.para: For the preparation of virus samples for transmission electron microscopy, virus particles were purified from the diseased bougainvillea tissues according to the methods described by de Silva et al. (2002) and Adomako et al. (1983) with slight modifications. In brief, the diseased leaves were homogenised in the extraction buffer [0.25 M Tris–HCl (pH 7.4) containing 0.5% (w/v) sodium sulphite, 4% (w/v) polyvinyl pyrrolidone 40, 0.5% (v/v) 2-mercaptoethanol and 0.25% diethyldithio-carbamic acid] with a tissue blender. The sap was clarified through muslin filtration and then added slowly with Triton X-100 (final concentration of 2%) under room temperature. The sample was clarified again through centrifugation 4 (12 000 g for 20 min at 10℃). The supernatant was mixed with polyethylene glycol (MW 6000) in the presence of 0.2 M NaCl and kept at 4℃ for 4.5 h. The resulting pellets were resuspended overnight in 60 mL TN buffer [50 mM Tris–HCl (pH 7.4) and 150 mM NaCl] and centrifuged again (12 000 g for 10 min at 4℃). The supernatant was ultracentrifuged (150 000 g for 2 h at 4℃) to precipitate the virus particles. The pellet was resuspended in 600μl Tris–buffer [50 mMTris–HCl (pH 7.0)].

To prepare the specimen for transmission electron microscopy, grids (200 meshes) were coated with supporting film (0.5% formvar in chloroform) and then treated with carbon coating and ion sputter. One drop (approximately 20μl) of the virus preparation as mentioned above was placed on the grid, incubated for 1 min and then removed by filter paper slip. Another drop of 1% phosphotungstic acid (PTA) was put on the grid for approximately 5 min for negative staining. The grid was dried in a vacuum desiccator after removing PTA. Finally, the specimen was examined under a transmission electron microscope (JEM 100 CXII; JOEL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan).

section.title: Nucleic acid preparation for PCR assays
section.para: The nucleic acid extracts for the PCR templates were prepared using the same method as described by Hung et al. (1999). In brief, bougainvillea leaf samples (approximately 500 mg) were homogenised in the nucleic acid extraction buffer [0.1 M Tris–HCl (pH 8.0), 0.05 M ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), 0.5 M NaCl, 1% N-lauroylsarcosine] and incubated at 55℃ for 1 h. After low-speed (4000 g) centrifugation, the supernatant was treated with 1% hexadecyl-trimethyl-ammoniumbromide at 65℃ for 10 min. The nucleic acid was precipitated (12 000 g) with isopropanol after chloroform/ isoamyl alcohol (24:1) and phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) treatments. The nucleic acid pellet was resuspended in 150μl TE buffer (pH 8.0).

section.title: Primers and polymerase chain reaction conditions
section.para: Two opposing primers, based on the published sequences of the conserved region of replicase in Badnavirus genomes (Bouhida et al., 1993), were selected in the PCR assay to amplify the BsCVBV-specific fragments for cloning and sequencing. The primer pair (named Badnavirus – 0.67 kb), composed of the forward primer 5’-TCA AAGTTT GAT TTG AAG AGC GGG-3’ and the reverse primer 5’-CTT GCA TAC TGC TCC CCA TCC-3’, were designed to amplify a BsCVBV-specific 0.67 kb fragment by PCR.

Another primer pair (named BsCVBV-1), derived from the sequences of our cloned BsCVBV-specific DNA fragments as described above, was designed for the BsCVBVspecific PCR amplification. Primer pair BsCVBV-1, composed of the forward primer 5’-ACA GCG ATT TCA TTGCTG TG-3’ and the reverse primer 5’-GAC TAG TTC TCGATC AGA AGG-3’, was designed to amplify a 413-bp fragment for the rapid detection of BsCVBV by PCR.

Polymerase chain reaction was performed using 25μl of reaction mixture containing 20 mM Tris–HCl (pH8.4), 50 mM KCl, 4 mM MgCl2, 0.2 mM each dATP, dTTP, dCTP and dGTP, 50 ng of each primer, 0.75 units of Taq DNA polymerase (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA) and 250 ng template DNA. Thermal cycling conditions were as follows: one cycle at 94℃ for 3 min; 30 cycles at 94℃ for 1 min, 60℃ for 1 min and 72℃ for 2 min, followed by a 72℃ extension for 10 min. Reactions were carried out in a DNA thermal cycler (GeneAmp PCR System 2400; Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA).

section.title: Analysis of PCR products by electrophoresis
section.para: Polymerase chain reaction products were analysed by gel electrophoresis using 1.4% agarose in TAE buffer (40 mM Tris–acetate, 1 mM EDTA, pH8.0). After electrophoresis (100 V for 30 min), products in the gel were stained with ethidium bromide (0.5μg mL-1 ), visualised and analysed by the AlphaImager 2000 Documentation & Analysis System (Alpha Innotech Co., San Leandro, CA, USA). A 100-bp DNA Ladder set (Promega, Madison, WI, USA) was included to determine fragment size.

section.title: Nucleotide sequencing and sequence analysis
section.para: Polymerase chain reaction products were clarified using a High Pure PCR Product Purification kit (Roche Applied Science, Mannheim, Germany) and then cloned by a TOPO TA Cloning kit (Invitrogen) according to the protocols supplied by the manual. The recombinant plasmids with specific DNA fragments were checked and selected by PCR amplification with the degenerate primers as described previously, and they were replicated and purified through minipreparation using a Qiaprep Spin Miniprep kit (QIAGEN, Hilden, Germany). DNA sequencing was conducted using ABI PRISM Dye Terminator Cycle Sequencing Ready Reaction kit (Applied Biosystems) and analysed in an ABI PRISM 310 Genetic Analyzer (Applied Biosystems) as recommended by the manufacturer. Primers used for sequencing were M13- reverse and T7 universal primers. The determined nucleotide sequences were further analysed and aligned by the MegAlign module in DNASTAR Lazergene software (DNASTAR Inc., Madison, WI, USA) as well as the Basic Local Alignment Search Tool provided from the National Center for Biotechnology Information.
